results.title: Paul Jacob and the nuclear gang
results.creator_credit: Jack Willis, Center for Documentary Media and Saul Landau
results.brief_description: Opening with a 1951 speech by US President Harry S. Truman, this documentary explores the data gathered by investigative reporter Paul Jacobs on the long range effects of low level radiation and exposes the attempts by the US Government to keep this information from the public. In 1957, on the advice of Linus Pauling, Jacobs went to several small towns in Utah and Arizona to substantiate reports that people there had been exposed to radioactive fallout from the Nevada atomic test. It became evident from his work over the following years that the incidence of cancer and leukemia was much higher there than in other areas. The film covers exposure to atomic fallout by civilians around the government’s Nevada site in the 1950’s and early 60’s and the soldiers who were participants in the nuclear bomb tests. Also looks at the problems [today] facing workers at the government’s nuclear facilities at Hanford, Washington and Portsmouth, New Hampshire. Interviews civilian residing near the Rocky Flats, Colorado nuclear plant. The reporter’s probe ended with his death in 1978, a month after this documentary was filmed. His death has been attributed to a rare form of lung cancer which his doctors believe he contracted investigating the story in 1957. Includes extracts from films produced in the 1950’s promoting the government’s safety practices. Also among those interviewed are Dr Thomas Mancuso, Dr Helen Caldicott and representatives of the US Defense Nuclear Agency and Department of Energy. (Awards: Mannheim Film Festiva)

results.brief_description: Presents a series of reflections in water against a musical backdrop with no narration. Designed to convey the beauty and serenity of nature.

results.title: Patterns of time and distance
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Otton, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Edwin Moses
results.brief_description: Sets out the overall pattern of Australia’s development from timeless isolation to our modern urbanised society considering “the changing Australia”, and the problems change generates. Through communications and transport ideas are transmitted to this southern continent. A film of concepts owing much to Philbrick’s area organisation of the world. FDA NO: 1809

results.title: Patterns of subsistence: the hunter-gatherers and pastoralists
results.creator_credit: Ira R. Abrams, Harry Ratner, Holt, Rinehart and Winston and Coast Community College District
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Faces of culture”.
For two million years we were hunter-gatherers. For the Bushmen of the Kalahari, it is still the way of life that is best suited to their environment. Women’s work counts for 85% of the group’s diet. The men provide the meat. The first half of this program covers various peoples around the world who still hunt and gather as the main form of their subsistence. The second half deals with the pastoralists. In semi-arid lands, with little water for crops pastoralism provides an ingenious adaptation to the needs of food production. Instead of hunting prey, it would be collected and protected in herds. Covers Netsilik Eskimos, Tribesmen of Africa’s Sudan and Tribesmen of Iran. Narrated by David Carradine.

results.title: Patterns of subsistence: the food producers
results.creator_credit: Ira R. Abrams, Harry Ratner, Holt, Rinehart and Winston and Coast Community College District
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Faces of culture”.
This program covers the invention of food production, horticulture and agriculture. Notions of property and ownership came about due to the advent of horticulture. The domestication of plants brought about a drastic change in our way of life. Covers Melanesian villages where the principle crop is the yam, Cambodia in ancient Angkor where sophisticated irrigation systems were invented. Also covers the use of tools for farming, eg. the use of draught animals and machines, fertiliser and herbicides. Program goes on to compare the modern world, how wheat provides its subsistence and how many of us have lost contact with the land. Narrated by David Carradine.

results.title: Patterns of heredity
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Eye on Research”.
What happens to human cells in certain cases of blood cancer? Can mongolism be inherited? What makes us grow old? In this study of the research being made into heredity, questions such as these are considered.

results.title: Patterns in flax
results.brief_description: The 6 foot leaves of New Zealand’s native flax were invaluable mats and baskets from the almost unbreakable flax strips and made cloth and rope from the tough fibres. New modern factories use some of the beautiful old Maori designs to make modern floor coverings. Often the modern weaving machines are operated by descendants of the Maoris who used these fibres to make the fine material for their garments.

results.title: Pattern, purpose and prospect
results.brief_description: This British documentary promotes the benefits to industry of new computing technology. A prescient film; as well as arguing the necessity of adapting computers to commercial and industrial applications, it anticipates the ubiquity of digital technology in the years to follow. This film is part of the epicentre of a high-nerd aesthetic of colourfully geeky enthusiasm for cheesy electronic technology.

results.title: Pattern of Britain: north east corner
results.creator_credit: Ralph Keene, Green Park Productions and John Eldridge
results.brief_description: A study of the communities in the extreme north-west area of Scotland, which, once dependent on fishing for their livelihood, are today becoming increasingly dependent on agriculture. Features the area’s main city of Aberdeen. The story is told by an old fisherman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ralph Keene, Green Park Productions and John Eldridge

results.title: Pattern interpretation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sewing”.
Discusses such problems as the interpretation of markings on various well-known commercial patterns; how to determine pattern size, yardage required, and the interpretation of pattern instructions.
